Lesson 4: How to Add JavaScript to an HTML File

Giving the Blueprint Its Instructions

You've written a recipe, but how do you get it into the cookbook?

We know JavaScript is the "brain" and the console is our "testing lab," but neither of those actually puts JavaScript into our project. Our website only knows about our .html file. So, how do we tell the browser to run our JavaScript code when it loads our page? We need a special tag that acts like a built-in instruction manual inside our HTML document.

Exercise 3: Predict the Order of Events

If you open an HTML file with the following code in the body, in what order will the alerts appear on your screen? Will "First" or "Second" appear first? Think about how a browser reads a file.

Multiple Scripts




Some text in between.

The alert box saying "First" will appear first, and then the alert saying "Second" will appear after you close the first one.

The browser reads and executes the HTML file from top to bottom. It will encounter the first script block, run the `alert("First")` command, and pause. Only after you dismiss that alert will it continue reading the file, find the second script block, and run `alert("Second")`.

Lesson 4: How to Add JavaScript to an HTML File

We know what JavaScript does, so let's learn how to actually "wire it up" to our HTML page so the browser can execute our commands.

The Special Ingredient

You have a recipe for a cake, and a separate note for a secret, magical frosting. How do you combine them?

Your HTML file is like a detailed recipe for a cake. It tells the browser exactly how to structure the page, step by step. Your JavaScript code is like a separate, special ingredient—a magical frosting that can make the cake sparkle. If you just hand the browser the recipe, it will make a plain cake. It has no idea the frosting even exists.
